Dear Megan Zambiasi:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at 517-899-6024.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Deborah Will, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Intervention standards and prohibitions
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(iv)Verbal abuse including the use of derogatory or
discriminatory language including negative references to a youth’s
background or appearance or mental state. Yelling, threats,
ridicule, or humiliation are strictly prohibited.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff 1 yelled at, cursed and verbally attacked Youth R, Youth K,
Youth O, Youth M and Youth P.
Investigation DCWL received this investigation on 4/24/24.
I collaborated with the Placement Coordination Unit, Foster Care
Workers for Youth R, Youth K, Youth O, Youth M and Youth P
were notified that I was assigned to investigate the allegations and
no workers expressed additional licensing concerns.
Interviews:
I interviewed Youth M on 4/26/24 with Rights Officer present.
She described Staff 1 as “a loud person” who expresses herself in
a “different” way. Youth M denied Staff 1 has ever been verbally
abusive to her or other youths. She could not recall Staff 1
swearing or saying anything inappropriate.
I interviewed Youth R on 4/26/24 with Rights Officer present. She
described Staff 1 as “mean, loud, picks with us and yells about our
chores.” Youth R said Staff 1 made a general statement that if a
youth “puts hands on her she would put hands on them, but lots of
staff probably say that when they are mad.” Youth R recalled one
specific instance in March 2024 when Staff 1 used abusive
language and made an offensive comment related to her trauma.
2

Youth R later retracted that Staff 1 made this remark. (See Rule
112 below).
I interviewed Youth K on 4/26/24 with Rights Officer present. She
appeared angry, was short and resisted the interview. Youth K
described Staff 1 as a “bitch” who has cussed at her. She was
tired of discussing the matter and remarked, “I don’t care about
this anymore.” Youth K said Staff 1 told her she stunk but she
refused to elaborate. She walked out of the interview yelling,
“Yes. I said I’m safe. I’m safe. I’m safe.” Rights Officer reported
this matter was already addressed internally with Staff 1.
On 4/26/24 I interviewed Youth O with Rights Officer present.
She was angry and said I was “wasting her time for no reason.”
Youth O said Staff 1 referred to her as a “half breed,” that Youth O
was “pissed off” about it and Former Youth H heard her say it.
Youth O had no other opinions about Staff 1. She said she and
Staff 1 have not reconciled or talked about the alleged name-
calling. Rights Officer reported this was matter was already
addressed in a Special Plan for Safety and Adjustment dated
4/8/24.
I interviewed Youth P at Havenwyck Hospital on 5/2/24. She
described Staff 1 as “very disrespectful and always yells and
cusses.”
I interviewed Former Youth H on 4/29/24 via phone. She
explained she was in the kitchen when Youth O was cussing and
calling people the “N” word regardless of their race. “Staff 1 told
Youth O, ‘You shouldn’t say that word because you’re half-breed.”
Former Youth H also reported when she was at the facility that
Staff 1 told her she (Former Youth H) was “fat and needed to lose
weight.”
I interviewed Supervisor with Rights Officer present. She has
worked at the facility for 19 years and supervises Staff 1.
Supervisor denied ever hearing Staff 1 yell at, cuss or verbally
attack any of the youth. Conversely Supervisor said Midnight
Team Leader remarked in front of her, Youth P and others that
Staff 1 was “triggering Youth P.” “I removed Midnight Team
Leader, had her step away from Staff 1 and told Midnight Team
Leader she should not say those things in front of youth.”
Supervisor said Midnight Team Leader and Staff 1 have
complained about each other to her and she encouraged Midnight
Team Leader to talk to her own supervisor on midnight shift.
3

On 4/26/24 I interviewed Staff 1 with Rights Officer present. She
has worked at the facility for nine months. Staff 1 denied using
abusive language and making an insensitive remark to Youth R
related to her trauma. “That didn’t happen. I don’t know about
Youth R’s situation (trauma)” she insisted.
Staff 1 denied telling Youth K she stinks, adding that this alleged
incident was already addressed internally by Rights Officer. Staff
1 stated, “Whatever Youth K told Midnight Team Leader is not
true.” She went on to explain that she used to work the midnight
shift with Midnight Team Leader. “I found Midnight Team Leader
unprofessional so in mid-February 2024 I moved to dayshift.”
Staff 1 was asked if she called Youth O a “mixed breed mutt” and
described her interaction with the youth. Staff 1 said “I redirected
Youth O not to say the “N” word and asked her to step out of the
kitchen. The next day I heard I told her she was a mixed breed,”
which she denied saying. Staff 1 confirmed a written plan was
devised so she would not be alone with Youth O in order to
protect her (Staff 1) from further allegations.
Staff 1 denied she verbally attacked Youth M and Youth P on
4/24/24. Instead, she said she redirected the girls with Supervisor
present. Moreover, Staff 1 said Midnight Team Leader stepped in
and said Staff 1 was “triggering Youth P” in front of Supervisor,
Youth P and other youths. Staff 1 felt it was inappropriate for
Midnight Team Leader to undermine her in front of the youths.
Documents reviewed:
I reviewed a Special Plan for Safety and Adjustment dated 4/8/24.
The plan indicated Youth O and Staff 1 will not engage in
conversations that are not about meeting Youth O’s needs at the
current moment and Staff 1 is only able to be on Youth O’s wing
with another staff member.
I reviewed an email to Rights Officer by the author of the Safety
Plan indicating its purpose was/is to promote comfort to Youth O
and Staff 1 and prevent further allegations against Staff 1.
Analysis Rights Officer and Vista Maria’s team had already looked into
most of these matters, intervened and addressed them with Staff
1 prior to this investigation commencing. Despite the facility’s
internal processes being underway, Midnight Team Leader still
brought them to the attention of Children’s Protective Services and
DCWL.
4

The licensing rule prohibits verbal abuse, derogatory or
discriminatory language, negative references to a youth’s
background, appearance or mental state as well as yelling,
threats, ridicule, and humiliation.
While it is difficult to prove that certain words were uttered, three
youths stated Staff 1 yells and/or cusses, two reported she made
a negative reference to Youth O’s racial background and two
others said she made negative references to youths’ physical
appearance/body odor.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code Program statement
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care, safety,
and supervision, methods for addressing residents’ needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth P was on one-to-one supervision and left alone for 40
minutes.
Investigation Interviews:
Youth P could not be interviewed immediately as she was at the
hospital awaiting a psychiatric evaluation. On 4/26/24 Rights
Officer indicated there was a plan to transfer her to Havenwyck
Hospital.
I interviewed Youth P on 5/2/24 at the psychiatric hospital. She
said on the morning of 4/24/24 she was on 1:1 staff supervision
for self-harm and was left alone for what she estimated was two
hours.
Supervisor said on 4/24/24 at 7am Staff 2 was Youth P’s
assigned 1:1 staff. When she walked into the building, Youth P
was sitting alone in the living area and Staff 2 was in the hallway
about 12 feet away. “I told Staff 2 she needed to be ‘on the young
lady’ meaning arms distance away. Supervisor said Midnight
Team Leader was still in charge in the building and should have
been the person to correct Staff 2.
5

I interviewed Staff 2 with Rights Officer on 5/1/24. She has
worked at the facility for six months and has 11 years of
experience working in child caring institutions. At 7am on 4/24/24
Staff 2 said Midnight Team Leader was in charge at Myriam Hall.
There were two youths on 1:1 and “Midnight Team Leader got to
screaming at me and Staff 1 that no one was Youth P’s 1:1. I went
to Youth P and stayed with her the rest of the day.” Asked who
and how 1:1’s are assigned, she said direct care staff “assign
each other and work it out amongst each other.”
I interviewed Midnight Team Leader with Rights Officer via video
conference on 5/3/24. She said she went to Myriam Hall at 7am
on 4/24/24 to assist staff. When she arrived, there was no other
Dayshift Team Leader or Supervisor in the building because the
assigned Team Leader was running late. After passing morning
medications, Midnight Team Leader said she noticed Youth P
sitting alone at 7:30am, which she considered child neglect as she
required 1:1 supervision for self-harm. Midnight Team Leader
said she was not aware there were two 1:1’s that morning. I
asked Midnight Team Leader if she assigned herself or any of the
direct care staff to monitor Youth P on 1:1. She said she was
unable to be the youth’s assigned 1:1 staff but “subliminally
became her 1:1.” Midnight Team Leader struggled and could not
explain what she meant by “subliminally.”
Video:
Footage on 4/24/24 showed Youth P exit her room at 7:18am and
walk around the unit alone until Staff 2 paired with her at 7:41am.
Documents reviewed:
I reviewed Vista Maria’s Client Observation Policy which indicates
for youth on 1:1 supervision, staff will remain with the youth at all
times and must never leave the client without replacement staff
available to provide uninterrupted observation.
I reviewed Youth P’s Observation Checklist dated 4/24/24 which
indicated Youth P was on 1:1 status for self-harm and Staff 2
documented her activities at 7:15am, 7:30am, 7:45am and
beyond.
Analysis Youth P was on 1:1 supervision for self-harm. Video showed
Youth P did not have a staff person by her side for 23 minutes.
Midnight Team Leader, staff and Youth P indicated after exiting
her room in the morning, Youth P did not receive 1:1 staff
supervision for a relatively short period of time.
CONSULTATION
6

Supervisors/Team Leaders should identify staffing needs at the
beginning of each shift based on youth acuity. Supervisors/Team
Leaders should assign specific staff to specific youths requiring
1:1 supervision, clearly communicate this to the staff and
document the assignments. If staffing gaps exist, I recommend
Supervisors/Team Leaders/Case Managers/Unit Managers fill the
gaps temporarily until direct care staff relief arrives.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code Criminal history check, subject to requirements; staff qualifications
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4112
Section (4) A person with ongoing duties shall have both of the following:
Description (a) Ability to perform duties of the position assigned.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Midnight Team Leader told Youth R to lie about Staff 1 when she
was interviewed.
Investigation Interviews:
I interviewed Youth R again on 4/29/24 with Rights Officer via
video conference. She admitted that before her interview on
4/26/24, Midnight Team Leader came to her room and told her to
lie when she was asked about Staff 1. Specifically, Midnight
Team Leader told her to say that Staff 1 had remarked, “That’s
why you fucked your brother” and if she did not say this, Midnight
Team Leader would lie to everyone about Youth R.
Midnight Team Leader admitted she did talk to Youth R alone in
her room but denied she coached her on what to say about Staff
1. Instead, she only confirmed with Youth R that she reported the
story correctly to Children’s Protective Services as Youth R had
previously told her. Asked why Youth R would say Midnight Team
Leader coached her, she assumed Staff 1 had said it.
Midnight Team Leader believes issues began between her and
Staff 1 after she reported Staff 1 internally for using abusive
language. “Staff 1 is disrespectful to me, yet I still do my job.” I
asked Midnight Team Leader if she undermined Staff 1 by
correcting her in front of the youths. She did not recall doing that
and said she tries to support staff. Midnight Team Leader
believes she can continue working with Staff 1 without further
disputes.
7

I asked Midnight Team Leader what Vista Maria can do to assure
there are no gaps in staffing particularly for those youths requiring
1:1 supervision. She responded, “Maybe a pay raise.”
At the end of the interview Midnight Team Leader referred to Vista
Maria as “a hostile environment for staff and youth.” She clarified
“It’s more staff verbally abusing each other than staff verbally
abusing kids.” I asked if Midnight Team Leader trusted that Vista
Maria’s management team and administrators would or could
solve these internal issues. She responded, “No.”
Analysis Midnight Team Leader has an idealistic view of what it takes to
operate a large child caring institution. She does not seem to
understand the myriad of factors affecting how staffing patterns
can change on an hourly basis and does not trust Vista Maria’s
leadership to address and follow through on her complaints.
Despite the facility’s internal processes being underway, Midnight
Team Leader brought the matters to the attention of Children’s
Protective Services and DCWL seemingly due to vindictiveness
toward Staff 1.
Midnight Team Leader’s personal issues and lack of trust in her
employer and others negatively impacts her ability to perform the
duties of her assigned position.
CONSULTATION
I recommend Midnight Team Leader and Staff 1 not work together
in any capacity and that any complaints one has about the other
be handled internally by the facility.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
